text:
For many people, the cockroach
seems indestructible.

But one insect in particular
has a unique, even ghoulish

ability to break
down its defenses:
the emerald wasp.

It doesn’t just kill the
cockroach, it enslaves it.

First, the wasp
injects the roach
with mind-controlling venom.
That subdues the roach.

The wasp then leads it to its
nest like a dog on a leash.

There, it lays an
egg on the cockroach.

That egg turns
into a larva that

burrows into the
zombie roach and eats
it alive from the inside out.
What can a poor cockroach do?

Not much is known about the
roach’s defenses, but it does

have one surprisingly
effective move.
[whack]

Kenneth Catania, a biologist
at Vanderbilt University,

investigated the initial
wasp-roach confrontation.

He set up a series
of high-speed cameras

and then put the two
insects together.
Here’s what happened.

There’s a flurry of action
as they wrestle for control.

Suddenly, the cockroach
unleashes a kind of karate

kick straight at
the wasp’s head.
[whack]
Let’s watch it again.

The cockroach turns away from
the wasp, raises its body
and strikes.
[whack]

Those spikes on
its leg? They’re
like barbed wire on a bat.

Sometimes, the roach
just shakes off the wasp
without a kick.

That’s what it’s
trying to do here.

When the roaches fought back,
about two-thirds of them escaped.

Roaches that didn’t
defend themselves,

they got stung
almost every time.

If you’re a cockroach,
clearly, you’ve
got to go for the kick.
Just don’t miss.
